metadata.subject: Trump meets with docs today as Congress preps Obamacare repeal

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
Department of Housing and Urban Development

relationships.description: Bannon served as senior counselor to President-elect Trump
Meeting with top healthcare executives to discuss Obamacare reform
Laura Perlmutter donated $2 million to Marco Rubio's campaign super PAC

transactions: Political donation to Marco Rubio's super PAC

analysis.purpose: To report on Donald Trump's meeting with healthcare executives and provide background on the participants
analysis.significance: Documents early transition meetings between Trump and healthcare industry leaders regarding Obamacare repeal and reform

notable_quotes: "We're really talking about replace and repair, rather than repeal. But we haven't seen a full approach yet from the administration." - John Noseworthy
"The number of quality metrics that we have to report to the government every year is just going up like crazy. We're now reporting well over 100 quality metrics on a regular basis." - Toby Cosgrove

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this news article

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article reporting on a meeting, not first-hand illegal activity

details: Article references multiple media outlets: Reuters, Washington Post, New York Times, MSNBC, NBC, CNBC
Written by journalist Borys Krawczeniuk and includes content from Ariana Eunjung Cha of Washington Post
Discusses media coverage of Trump's meetings with various industry leaders

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be a publicly available news article about Trump's transition meetings, likely published as part of routine political reporting

analysis.summary: News article detailing President-elect Donald Trump's December 28, 2016 meeting with top healthcare executives at Mar-a-Lago to discuss Obamacare repeal and reform, including leaders from Mayo Clinic, Johns Hopkins, Cleveland Clinic, and Partners HealthCare, along with background on the participants and their political connections.
